A customer is in the early planning stages of a technology rebuild. To gain a better understanding of the possible solutions, which of the following documents should the customer send to prospective vendors?

discussion.content: C is correct
should be RFP

Selected Answer: C
To gain a better understanding of the possible solutions for a technology rebuild, the customer should send a Request for Information (RFI) document to prospective vendors. An RFI is a document that is used to gather information from vendors about their products, services, and capabilities. It is typically sent to vendors early in the planning process to help the customer understand the range of solutions available, and to inform the development of more detailed requests for proposal (RFP) documents later on in the process. The RFI should include the customer's requirements, objectives, and any other relevant information that will help vendors understand the scope of the project.

Request for Information (RFI): An RFI is used when you need to gather more information about the goods or services you need to procure. This process will give you a sense for the number of providers or contractors who can provide the goods or services, and you will get an idea of cost. An RFI or RFQ is used when the costs are unknown to you and you need an estimate for the goods or services.
Request for Proposal (RFP): An RFP is submitted when you are ready to procure and begin the work. This process includes submitting the SOW, receiving bids from vendors and suppliers, evaluating the responses, and making a selection.

Selected Answer: C
C. Project deliverables completed behind schedule is the BEST indicator of project failure.

While each of the options listed could be a potential problem for a project, completing project deliverables behind schedule is the most significant and critical indicator of project failure. Meeting project timelines is a fundamental measure of project success, and delays in project completion can lead to cost overruns, missed opportunities, and loss of stakeholder trust. In contrast, product deficiencies, disagreements among team members, and changes to the project are all issues that can be addressed and resolved through effective project management practices, provided that the project stays on schedule. However, falling behind schedule can impact all aspects of the project, making it much more challenging to achieve success and meet stakeholder expectations.

A. RTM (Requirements Traceability Matrix) component is missing.

The RTM is a document that links requirements to the corresponding test cases and verifies that each requirement is fulfilled by the system. It is a critical component of the testing process and ensures that the system meets the requirements of the stakeholders. In this scenario, the stakeholders who are available for the user acceptance test do not understand the project's requirements, indicating that there may be a gap in the requirements gathering process or that the requirements have not been clearly defined and documented. The tester is trying to identify who requested the feature, but there is no information available, which further indicates that the requirements have not been effectively traced and documented in the RTM. Without a complete and accurate RTM, it can be challenging to identify the origin of a feature or requirement, and stakeholders may not have a clear understanding of what to expect from the system.

Selected Answer: A
The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) is a tabular document that links the project or
product requirements to their origin and traces them throughout the project life cycle. It links each requirement to the business and project objectives, Work Breakdown Structure, product design and development, and test scenarios. It ensures that approved requirements in the requirements documentation are met at the end of the project. The RTM also provides a structure for managing changes to the project or product scope.

Quality Inspection
Quality control almost always includes some form of inspection. The Quality Management Plan should identify the following three things:

Type of Inspection: The item that will be inspected and the inspection equipment that will be used. Also, the degree or level of inspection.
Frequency: The time between inspections and spacing relative to unique events (such as replacement of machine supplies, etc.)?
Criteria: The pass/fail criteria, or sliding scale (1-10) which will be reported.
Ideally an inspection form is developed or taken from a relevant source. It is important to be comprehensive and include all items necessary for a complete inspection, or else you could find yourself without the data you really want.
